title: (x) One of a kind - Modern No. 20 (customized) {Mike Y, Mark S}
content: Haha, you can put your finger on it, someone else already did i think ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050816105255im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
author: promotype

comments.content: I think this is a modeification of a Modern font, such as ITC Modern No. 20. If you just cover up those missing serifs I think you get this look.

Here is a simulation of this, compared to the original. I used ITC Modern No. 216 in Light weight. I can see I should have used heavier, but this demonstrates the idea. I made blank white squares/rectangles to block off parts of the top serifs and most of the foot serifs. I think this is how it was done.   
 ![One of a Kind sim](http://web.archive.org/web/20050816105255im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/41336.gif)

Doug, The reason I picked Modern was the very long tail on the 'a', but I can see Bodoni is also very similar. It is the sort of font that T-26 or maybe Psy-Ops could have, but I couldn't find one. I like the simple approaches for making 'one of a kind' titles, and blocking out parts of letters is easier than modifying letter outlines, or designing a new font.   
   
Sometimes it's even easier than finding an obscure font that might not exist.

I think this would be [Modern No. 20](http://web.archive.org/web/20050816105255/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/modern-no-20/modern-no-20/testdrive.html?s=one%a0of%a0a%a0kind&p=48), the old Stephenson Blake face, not the ITC one. With the serifs lopped off, as you say Mike, and stretched.
Yes, I agree Mark. I mentioned No. 20 in my first response, but the version I had looked too far off the sample and so I used the ITC font to demonstrate the way I thought it was done.
